propositions.text: This document contains the story "人皮信封" by 狼七.
The story is available online at http://www.xiaoshuotxt.com/xuanyi/7100/
The website http://www.xiaoshuotxt.com is described as a literary website.
The website offers classic literary masterpieces, martial arts novels, romance novels, and humanities and social science books for online reading.
TXT e-books are available for free download and reading on mobile phones.
Chapter 1 is titled "楔子" (Prologue).
The narrator hesitates to write about their experiences and observations.
The narrator finally gathers the courage to record everything after a person involved in the matter passes away.
The narrator claims the events are true, even if they seem unbelievable.
The narrator's life was ordinary and peaceful about a year ago.
A specific event changed the narrator's life.
Friends told the narrator that the story would either mean they are crazy or it only happens in stories.
Chapter 2 is titled "初涉邮差(1)" (First Steps as a Postman (1)).
The narrator's name is Luo Ze.
Luo Ze was a postman until about six months prior to the current narration.
After graduating from high school, Luo Ze took a job as a postman in a poor county in Chengde.
Luo Ze's delivery route was in the mountainous areas of the county.
Luo Ze's first bicycle was old and in poor condition.
The conditions of the job were described as difficult.
Five people were hired as postmen at the same time.
The postmen were described as 'three-no' personnel: no insurance, no subsidies, and no wives.
The county had poor transportation due to the mountains, making postmen a vital link to the outside world.
On the first day, the director gave Luo Ze a tattered map.
The director, Mr. Wang, was a middle-aged man with a stern expression, known as 'Fatty Wang' by others.
Mr. Wang asked Luo Ze if he could understand the map.
Luo Ze, needing the job, nodded and said he understood.
Luo Ze's postman life began.
Luo Ze worked for about a month, sometimes staying overnight in abandoned villages due to long delivery distances.
When Luo Ze went to get his contract for full-time employment, the other four new postmen were dejected.
Cao Laonian, a colleague of Luo Ze, stopped him and warned him not to deliver a red envelope.
Luo Ze knocked on the director's door.
Mr. Wang appeared to smile, but it made Luo Ze uneasy.
Luo Ze presented his contract for signature.
Mr. Wang explained that there was a shortage of staff and presented Luo Ze with a red envelope to deliver.
Mr. Wang promised Luo Ze would be made permanent if he delivered the letter.
Cao Laonian's prediction came true.
Luo Ze felt he had no choice but to accept the job, given its importance.
The red envelope had a peculiar, smooth texture, a one-yuan stamp, and no sender's address.
The recipient's address was written in calligraphy: Bei Gua Village, Group 3, Zeng Hao.
Luo Ze asked about the unfamiliar location.
Mr. Wang told him to ask Cao Laonian and the others.
Luo Ze left the office, and Cao Laonian rushed up to him.
Cao Laonian saw the red envelope and realized Luo Ze had accepted.
The other four postmen looked at Luo Ze with strange expressions, shifting from surprise to satisfaction.
Cao Laonian declared Luo Ze was "finished" and walked away.
Luo Ze felt an eerie chill and suspected something was amiss.
Cao Laonian found Luo Ze later to invite him to a farewell dinner.
The dinner atmosphere was tense and somber.
Cao Laonian warned Luo Ze to be careful going to Bei Gua Village.
Cao Laonian explained that Bei Gua Village was considered "evil" and "unclean," which is why no one wanted to go there.
Luo Ze initially dismissed their warnings.
Du Wei, another colleague, shared a story passed down from his father, a former postman.
Du Wei's father had a traumatic experience after delivering a letter to an unknown place.
After the delivery, Du Wei's father became reclusive, preferring to go out at night, and would often wake up screaming, "Don't kill me."
Du Wei's father eventually quit his job and became a taxi driver.
He died in a taxi accident soon after starting.
Du Wei's father's dying wish was for his son never to become a postman.
Du Wei revealed that the destination of his father's last delivery was Bei Gua Village.
Cao Laonian offered Luo Ze expensive cigarettes, implying it was a final gesture.
After dinner, Luo Ze accompanied Cao Laonian home.
Cao Laonian revealed he had faked his drunkenness to trick the others.
Cao Laonian took Luo Ze to his home and gave him a mysterious item wrapped in newspaper.
The item was a small, black box with strange carvings, left by Cao Laonian's deceased father.
Inside the box was a black stone that resembled solidified pitch.
Cao Laonian recounted his father's story of how he found the stone.
His father, while scavenging for valuables in a tomb, was trapped when the entrance was blocked.
He found a small passage and crawled through, hearing the sound of water.
The water turned into a powerful underground river.
His father eventually escaped through a cave opening, only to find himself at a cliff edge.
He jumped and landed on a platform in a large cave filled with animal skins and bones.
He heard rustling sounds and discovered a stone coffin with strange carvings and several jars nearby.
The jars contained "Yuan Datou" silver coins, and the last one held the black box.
Cao Laonian's father kept the box as a treasure.
Cao Laonian's father later worked at a power plant near an artificial lake.
Villagers avoided the lake, and people had gone missing from it.
Cao Laonian's father was warned by a friend, Sun Erhu, not to swim in the lake.
While swimming, Cao Laonian's father felt the water become extremely cold, and his legs went numb.
He found himself alone in the water, with thick black fog rising and a spectral white boat appearing.
He was unable to move, but a light from beneath him grew brighter.
The white boat disappeared, and he was pulled towards the surface.
Upon reaching the shore, he realized the light that saved him came from the black stone he carried.
Cao Laonian's father cherished the stone afterward until his death.
Cao Laonian gives the stone to Luo Ze, advising him to be careful and that he would explain more if Luo Ze returned.
Luo Ze, feeling uneasy, examines the red envelope and the stone.
The next morning, Luo Ze sets out for Bei Gua Village, feeling somewhat prepared.
The journey becomes difficult as rain starts and the roads turn to mountain paths.
Luo Ze leaves his bicycle at a substation in Daqi and continues on foot.
Bei Gua Village is surrounded by barren mountains, with a narrow valley overgrown with weeds.
Luo Ze is suddenly attacked by a small, dark, snake-like creature that bites his leg.
The creature is sticky and difficult to remove.
The bite causes a sharp, piercing pain.
Luo Ze tries to fight back with a sharp stone.
The creature exhibits exceptional jumping ability.
Luo Ze realizes the creature is legless and moves by coiling and jumping.
The creature taps its tail rhythmically on the ground, seemingly to summon others.
Several more of these creatures appear.
Luo Ze's leg becomes numb and swollen.
A "pheasant-like" creature suddenly appears and attacks the creatures biting Luo Ze.
An old man appears, wearing a straw hat and a white t-shirt, carrying a short, curved knife with a dragon carving.
The old man uses his knife to extract two black fangs from Luo Ze's wound.
He then retrieves the flesh of one of the creatures and tells Luo Ze to eat it.
Luo Ze finds the creature's flesh delicious and fragrant.
The old man identifies the creatures as "Di Kui" and explains they live in special conditions.
The "pheasant" is revealed not to be a wild pheasant.
The old man and the "pheasant" collect Di Kui.
Luo Ze learns that the Di Kui are buried in this area, along with 352 villagers from Bei Gua Village.
The old man invites Luo Ze to stay at his home in Nan Gua Village.
Chapter 4 is titled "诡异的村庄(1)" (The Strange Village (1)).
Nan Gua Village has unusually high courtyard walls and imposing doorways.
The house Luo Ze enters feels strangely familiar.
A boy named Jin Douzi, the old man's grandson, runs out to greet him.
Jin Douzi has large black eyes and appears energetic.
Inside the house, they find an altar with incense and strange objects.
Luo Ze is given dry clothes that fit him perfectly.
The old man, identified as Jin, becomes angry when he sees bones with strange carvings that Jin Douzi drew on.
Jin throws the carved bones into the stove.
Jin reveals that Jin Douzi is his grandson and that Jin Douzi is actually around Luo Ze's age, despite his appearance.
Jin recounts his daughter Hong Ying's story.
Hong Ying married Tang Jun from Daqi Town, and Jin Douzi was born shortly after.
Jin's family were hunters and later horse breeders.
One day, while hunting with Hong Ying, they chased a rabbit into a graveyard.
They entered the overgrown area and were suddenly plunged into darkness, experiencing what felt like a "ghost wall" (鬼打墙).
Jin used a traditional method of biting his middle finger and waving his blood to dispel the illusion.
He saw Hong Ying near a grave, with a dark shadow behind her.
He rushed to her, and the shadow disappeared.
Hong Ying was unwell and thirsty, and after waking up, she became weak.
Strange events began to occur in Jin's home after that night.
Jin and Tang Jun heard a strange procession with唢呐 (suona) music, gongs, and drums approaching their house at night.
Jin realized that their village was mostly deserted, making the procession unusual.
They extinguished the lamp and prepared to defend themselves.
Tang Jun investigated and found nothing outside.
The next morning, Jin discovered that one of their three water缸 (water vats) was missing, with no trace of water on the floor.

concepts.name: 邮差 (Postman)
concepts.context: The narrator's former profession and the central role in the story's beginning.

concepts.name: 信封 (Envelope)
concepts.context: Specifically a red envelope that plays a crucial role in the plot.

concepts.name: 北卦村 (Bei Gua Village)
concepts.context: A mysterious and dangerous destination for a delivery.

concepts.name: 罗泽 (Luo Ze)
concepts.context: The narrator and protagonist of the story.

concepts.name: 汪主任 (Director Wang)
concepts.context: The narrator's superior at the post office, referred to as 'Fatty Wang'.

concepts.name: 曹老蔫 (Cao Laonian)
concepts.context: A colleague of Luo Ze who warns him about the red envelope and provides crucial information.

concepts.name: 杜伟 (Du Wei)
concepts.context: A colleague of Luo Ze who shares a cautionary tale from his father.

concepts.name: 石头 (Stone)
concepts.context: A black stone given by Cao Laonian to Luo Ze, believed to have protective properties.

concepts.name: 地奎 (Di Kui)
concepts.context: Mysterious, snake-like creatures that attack Luo Ze.

concepts.name: 老头 (Old Man)
concepts.context: The mysterious old man in Nan Gua Village who helps Luo Ze and tells his story.

concepts.name: 金豆子 (Jin Douzi)
concepts.context: The grandson of the old man, who appears as a child but is revealed to be older.

concepts.name: 金 (Jin)
concepts.context: The surname of the old man and his family.

concepts.name: 南卦村 (Nan Gua Village)
concepts.context: The village where the old man lives, whose name is related to Bei Gua Village.

concepts.name: 诡异 (Strange/Eerie)
concepts.context: Describes the atmosphere of the village and events.

concepts.name: 故事 (Story)
concepts.context: Refers to the narrative being told and recounted.

concepts.name: 危险 (Danger)
concepts.context: Implied through warnings and encounters with creatures.

concepts.name: 神秘 (Mysterious)
concepts.context: Describes characters, objects, and events in the story.

main_topics: The Postman's Life and the Mysterious Task
Encounter with the Supernatural and Mysterious Aid
The Strange Village and its Inhabitants
hierarchy.structure: The document is structured chronologically through chapters, starting with a prologue and then detailing the protagonist's experiences as a postman leading to a dangerous assignment. Subsequent chapters focus on supernatural encounters, mysterious artifacts, and the unfolding of a village's strange history.
